title: Introduction to SQL
content:
SQL (Structured Query Language) is used to store, manage, and retrieve data in relational databases.
Popular SQL databases: MySQL, PostgreSQL, SQL Server, SQLite.

SQL is used to:
- Insert data
- Update records
- Delete records
- Retrieve (query) data
- Create tables & databases

title: Databases & Tables
INSERT Statement
content:
INSERT adds new records.
Use VALUES to insert row data.
Multiple rows can be inserted at once.

title: SELECT Statement
content:
SELECT retrieves data.
Use * to select all columns.
WHERE filters results.

title: WHERE Clause
content:
Filters results.
Operators: =, >, <, >=, <=, !=
Use LIKE for patterns.
codeExample: SELECT * FROM users WHERE name LIKE 'A%';

title: UPDATE & DELETE
content:
UPDATE modifies existing records.
DELETE removes rows.
Always use WHERE to avoid affecting all records.
codeExample:
UPDATE users SET name='Bob' WHERE id=1;
DELETE FROM users WHERE id=2;
trystarter: UPDATE users SET name='Test' WHERE id=3;

title: ORDER BY
codeExample: SELECT * FROM users ORDER BY name ASC;
trystarter: SELECT * FROM users ORDER BY id DESC;

title: LIMIT
content:
LIMIT restricts the number of returned rows.
Useful for pagination.

title: Aggregate Functions
content:
Aggregate functions:
- COUNT()
- SUM()
- AVG()
- MAX()
- MIN()
Usually used with GROUP BY.

title: GROUP BY
content:
GROUP BY groups rows with the same values.
Use HAVING to filter grouped results.
codeExample: SELECT name, COUNT(*) FROM users GROUP BY name;
trystarter: SELECT id, COUNT(*) FROM users GROUP BY id;

title: Joins (INNER, LEFT, RIGHT)
content:
Joins combine rows from two tables.
INNER JOIN: matching rows only
LEFT JOIN: all left rows + matches
RIGHT JOIN: all right rows + matches
codeExample:
SELECT * FROM orders
INNER JOIN users ON orders.user_id = users.id;
trystarter: SELECT * FROM A INNER JOIN B ON A.id = B.id;

title: Full Outer Join
content:
Returns all rows from both tables whether matched or not.
Not supported in MySQL but can be simulated with UNION.
codeExample:
SELECT * FROM A
FULL OUTER JOIN B ON A.id = B.id;
trystarter: SELECT * FROM A FULL OUTER JOIN B ON A.id=B.id;

title: Constraints
content:
Constraints restrict data:
- PRIMARY KEY
- FOREIGN KEY
- UNIQUE
- NOT NULL
- CHECK

title: Indexes
content:
Indexes improve query performance.
Use on frequently searched columns.
Downside: increases write cost.

title: Views
content:
Views are virtual tables from SELECT statements.
They store no data and help simplify complex queries.
codeExample:
CREATE VIEW v_users AS
SELECT name FROM users;
trystarter: CREATE VIEW v_demo AS SELECT * FROM demo;
